About

I live in Seattle where I'm currently enrolled in Flatiron School's Data Science Program. Previously, I lived in Tokyo and worked as a translator from Japanese to English, and before that I had a 20 year stint in the Bible Belt. The two loves of my life are books and plastic forks (featured at left, I-Spy edition). Three quotes to live by:

石の上にも三年。'Even sitting on a rock, wait three years.'
– a Japanese proverb

Your target audience is your younger self.
– Dr. Jackson Crawford

Things taste better in small houses.
– Queen Victoria

Project: Predicting Heart Disease (binary Classification)

I tried out a bunch of different binary classifier to predict heart disease. I focused on exploring a variety of relatively simple classifiers (read: no neural networks)––Support Vector Machines, Decision Trees and Random Forests, AdaBoost and XGBoost, KNN––and fine tuning each to upwards of 85% accuracy on test data. My final model, an ensemble Voting Classifier, combines some of the best models to achieve 89% accuracy on test data. Find the full project on GitHub.

  • Date: July 2020
  • Category: Classification

Project: Predicting Housing Prices In King County

For my second Flatiron School project, I modeled house prices in King County, Washington against a number of predictors––square footage, number of bathrooms, year built, etc.––using multiple linear regression. The model was built for the purpose of inference moreso than prediction. Find the full project on GitHub.

  • Date: May 2020
  • Category: Linear Regression

Project: Exploring The Move Industry

I was given the following scenario for my Flatiron School Module 1: Project Microsoft has decided to enter the movie industry by creating its own movie studio, and has hired me to help them understand the industry. I performed an exploratory data analysis to present actionable insights to the company. Find the full project on GitHub.

  • Date: March 2020
  • Category: Exploratory Data Analysis
